The '''Haradrim''' or the '''Southrons''' were the proud and warlike people of the [[Harad]], in the south of [[Middle-earth]]. Ancient enemies of [[Gondor]], they allied with [[Sauron]] during the [[War of the Ring]].
== History ==
The ancestors of the Haradrim were [[Men]] who awoke in the [[First Age]], but stayed to the [[East]] of [[Middle-earth]], not joining the migration of the [[Edain]] to the [[West (disambiguation)
column2: West]]. They eventually settled in [[Harad]], where the [[Sun]] is fierce and there are no clouds. It is possible that they were relatives of the [[Easterlings (First Age)
column3: Swarthy Men]] who went to [[Beleriand]] after the Edain.

column1: In the [[Second Age]] [[Sauron]] escaped the judgment of the [[Valar]] and continued his former master's work, turning the Men of the [[East]] and [[South (disambiguation)
column2: South]] to evil and dominating them. Under the authority of the Dark Lord, many towns and walls of stone were built, and those under his influence became numerous and armed with iron. To these men, Sauron was feared as a king and god.<ref name=rings>{{S

column1: === Second Age ===
During the Second Age the [[Númenóreans
column2: High Men]] of [[Númenor]] built a great city in the firth of [[Umbar]], a vast natural harbour on the southern shores of the [[Bay of Belfalas]], eventually turning the city into a fortified citadel from whose gates the Men of Númenor initially benefited the people in the lands they explored by teaching them many things about agriculture and craftsmanship.<ref>{{App
column3: Numenor}}</ref> After the reign of [[Tar-Ciryatan]], the Númenóreans began to set themselves up as lords in Middle-earth as they demanded tribute of goods and wealth, causing the oppression of the Haradrim. Under [[Ar-Pharazon]], the Númenóreans made war on the Men of Middle-earth, enslaving them and using them for human sacrifices.<ref>{{S

column1: In the following centuries they were influenced by [[Sauron]] and [[Black Númenóreans]], those evil High Men who stayed in Harad and survived the [[Downfall of Númenor]].<ref>{{RK
column2: V10}}</ref> The Haradrim became enemies of [[Gondor]], as the Kingdom's southern borders were close to their lands. Shortly before the [[War of the Last Alliance]], two Númenórean lords, [[Herumor]] and [[Fuinur]], "rose to great power amongst the Haradrim".<ref name=rings/>

column1: === Third Age ===

The Haradrim did not trouble the [[Realms in Exile]] for many centuries. There were dealings between the southlands and Gondor in these days, though it is said that there was never friendship between the two realms.<ref name="herbs"/> When Gondor took the haven of [[Umbar]] from the [[Black Númenóreans]], in the year {{TA
column2: 1015}} they followed the Black Númenóreans against Umbar to recapture it. Their great power was not enough against the sea-power of Gondor. The attempts lasted for 35 years until, in {{TA
column3: 1050}}, [[Ciryaher]] defeated the Haradrim force by sending troops by land. They acknowledged the overlordship of Gondor; the kings of Harad did homage and their sons were given as hostages in the court of the [[Kings of Gondor

column1: Later however kings of Harad who were in league with the [[Umbar]] rebelled against Gondor. King [[Aldamir]] fell in battle against them but his son [[Vinyarion]] won a great victory in Harad in {{TA

The Haradrim later were allied with the [[Wainriders]], a confederation of [[Easterlings]], and the Men of [[Khand]]. During the simultaneous assaults from the north and the south, the South-kingdom came close to destruction. The campaigns ended with the Wainraiders' definite defeat in the [[Battle of the Camp]] in {{TA
Around that time, some Haradrim were among the [[Corsairs of Umbar]], a constant harassment for Gondor.<ref name=foster>{{HM
The Haradrim were stirred up by emissaries of Sauron to attack Gondor again, and in {{TA
column2: 2885}}, they did so at the [[Crossings of Poros]], but were defeated again as they faced also the [[Rohirrim]]. The [[twins
column4: King]] [[Folcwine]] of [[Rohan]], were slain in that battle.<ref>{{App

column1: At the time of the [[War of the Ring]], the Southrons were in league with [[Sauron]] and fought alongside his [[Orcs
column2: Orc]] army. The Haradrim were among the forces led by the [[Witch-king]] that attacked [[Osgiliath]] on [[20 June
column5: Great}}</ref> at the beginning of the War. They captured the eastern half of Osgiliath, but [[Boromir]] and [[Faramir]] cast down the bridge across the [[Anduin]] and defended the western half of the city.<ref name="Council">{{FR
column6: II2}}</ref> More Haradrim continued to come up the [[Harad Road]] to Mordor. Faramir and the [[Rangers of Ithilien]] ambushed some companies of Haradrim, but they could not stop them all.<ref name="herbs"/>

column1: In the [[Battle of the Pelennor Fields]], they deployed cavalry and gigantic, [[Elephants
column3: Mûmakil]]. Regiments of Haradrim joined the host from Minas Morgul marching to the [[Pelennor Fields]]. Sauron's forces besieged [[Minas Tirith]], and the Mûmakil of Harad were used to bring forward war-towers and siege-engines to test the City's defences. One of the leaders of the Haradrim at this time bore the standard of the [[Black Serpent]] and was slain by King [[Théoden]] of [[Rohan]] at the [[Battle of the Pelennor Fields]]<ref name=fields>{{RK

column1: Once Sauron was destroyed, Southrons in the western lands of Harad submitted to the rule of King [[Aragorn
column2: Elessar]] and were conquered. The Southrons in the East, however, remained independent.

column1: == Traits and culture ==
[[File:Alan Lee - Oliphaunt.jpg

The Haradrim were bold and grim men, fierce in despair. They were tall and dark-skinned with black hair and dark eyes, and for that they were called '''Swertings''' or '''[[Swarthy Men]]'''.<ref name="herbs">{{TT
column2: Herbs}}</ref> The men of [[Near Harad]] were brown-skinned, with black hair and dark eyes,<ref name="Gate">{{TT
column3: IV3}}</ref> while the race known as "[[Half-trolls
column4: half-trolls]]" out of [[Far Harad]] had black skin.<ref name=fields/>

column1: Many Haradrim warriors were seen in bright clothing, such as scarlet robes, and were decorated with golden ornaments, such as collars, earrings, corsets of overlapping brazen plates; they braided their hair with gold. Some tribes painted their bodies. Scarlet and red was also the color of their banners, tips of their spears, and body paint. Their shields were yellow and black with spikes.<ref name="herbs"/> It is also mentioned that at the end of the Second Age some of the Men in the south had weapons of iron.<ref name=rings/> At the Battle of the Pelennor Fields, the Haradrim bore scimitars that glittered like stars.<ref name=fields/>
The Haradrim had tamed the massive ''[[Oliphaunts
column2: Mûmakil]]'' beasts and used them in warfare and, like their masters, were decorated with scarlet and gold. They even strapped towers on their backs, used by Haradrim archers and spearmen.<ref name="herbs"/>

column1: Harad's tribes included into those of Near and Far Harad, although there were many tribes of the Haradrim, often mutually hostile. Some of the peoples of Far Harad were organized into kingdoms.<ref name="herbs"/>
===Language===
To the [[Gondorians]] their voices sounded harsh, like shouts of beasts.<ref>{{RK
The only word which is stated to come from a southron language is "Mûmak", the name of the great war-oliphaunts of Harad.
[[Gandalf]] states that his name in "the south" is "[[Incánus]]" thought ''Inkā-nūsh'' (or possibly ''Inkā-nūs''), meaning "North-spy".<ref>{{UT
Despite having a meaning in Quenya ("fate"), the name [[Umbar]] is said to be adapted from the natives' language and not from Elvish or [[Adûnaic]].
== Etymology ==
''Haradrim'' is a [[Sindarin]] name, consisting of the elements ''[[harad]]'' ("south") + ''[[rim]]'' ("host")<ref>{{L
Other names were '''Southerns''', '''Southrons'''.<ref name=foster/>
==Other versions of the Legendarium==
Early variant names for this people were the ''Barangils'',<ref>{{WR
column3: IV}}</ref> the ''Haradwaith'' (from the name of their land) and ''Haradrians''.<ref>{{HM

column1: Early [[Westron]] names include ''Harwan'' and ''Silharrows'', which are derived from the [[Old English]] name of the Aethiopians, ''Sigelhearwan'' (See also: ''[[Sigelwara Land]]'').<ref>{{TI

:The Haradrim appear briefly in [[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
column2: The Two Towers]] when Frodo and [[Samwise Gamgee
column3: Sam]] witness a raid on one of their columns by [[Faramir
column4: Faramir's]] rangers. They are featured more prominently in [[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King

column1: :While the [[The Return of the King
column2: book]] depicts the Southron army as primarily cavalry armed with scimitars, we see no horsemen in the movie: the Haradrim fight almost exclusively from platforms mounted on the backs of their monstrous [[oliphaunts]]. They have also adorned the animals' tusks with spikes and shafts that crush and impale numerous enemy horsemen.

column1: :The costumes of the Haradrim in the movie are Middle Eastern in style and dark brown or black in colour, while the Haradrim wore red livery in the book.
